explanation: The MRI reveals a mass in the brain, which has the appearance of a meningioma. The borders are well-defined, and the tumor appears to be extra-axial (arising outside the brain itself). This is consistent with the characteristics of a meningioma.
The MRI shows a diffuse, irregularly shaped mass in the brain parenchyma, with heterogeneous signal intensity. This is suggestive of a glioma.
The MRI scan shows a mass in the meninges, the membranes that surround the brain and spinal cord. This is consistent with a meningioma tumor.
The image shows a meningioma tumor.
The MRI shows a large, extra-axial mass with a broad dural base and dural tail, characteristic of a meningioma.
The MRI shows a large, irregularly shaped mass in the brain. This is consistent with a glioma tumor.
The MRI reveals a meningioma tumor.  The tumor originates from the meninges, the membranes that surround and protect the brain and spinal cord.
The MRI shows a large, extra-axial mass with a broad dural base. The mass is well-circumscribed and has a homogeneous appearance.
The MRI reveals a large, well-defined extra-axial mass with a broad dural base and homogeneous enhancement. This is characteristic of a meningioma.

The MRI scan reveals a diffuse, irregularly shaped mass in the brain parenchyma. The mass appears hyperintense on the T2-weighted image, indicating increased water content. These features are suggestive of a glioma, a type of tumor that originates from glial cells in the brain.
The MRI shows a large, extra-axial mass with a broad dural base and well-defined margins, consistent with a meningioma.
The MRI image reveals a homogenously enhancing extra-axial dural-based mass near the superior sagittal sinus. This is a classic appearance of a meningioma tumor.
The MRI image shows a mass with a well-defined border that displaces the surrounding brain tissue. This is characteristic of a meningioma tumor.

The MRI image shows a large, well-defined mass in the right frontal lobe. The mass is extra-axial, meaning it arises outside of the brain tissue, and it appears to be attached to the dura mater, the outermost layer of the meninges. These features are consistent with a meningioma tumor.
The MRI scan shows a mass that is consistent with a meningioma tumor.
The MRI scan shows a large, well-defined extra-axial mass with dural tail sign, which are characteristic of meningioma tumors.
The MRI shows a mass with a broad dural base and dural tail. This is the classical appearance of a meningioma tumor.

The MRI scan shows a glioma tumor, which is a type of tumor that originates in the glial cells of the brain.
The image shows a mass that appears to be attached to the dura, which is characteristic of a meningioma.
The MRI scan shows a diffuse, infiltrative tumor with irregular borders. This is characteristic of a glioma.
The MRI scan shows a glioma tumor. Glioma is a type of tumor that occurs in the brain and spinal cord. Gliomas begin in the glial cells that surround nerve cells and help them function.

The MRI shows a large, well-defined, extra-axial mass in the right frontal lobe. The mass is isointense to gray matter on T1-weighted images and hyperintense on T2-weighted images. There is no surrounding edema. These findings are suggestive of a meningioma.

The MRI shows a large, extra-axial mass with a broad dural base and dural tail. The mass appears to be well-circumscribed and is causing significant mass effect on the adjacent brain parenchyma. These features are consistent with a meningioma tumor.
